author: Beth Abbit
title: Tributes to Holocaust survivor Chaim Ferster who lived through eight concentration camps
text:
News Tributes to Holocaust survivor Chaim Ferster who lived through eight concentration camps Mr Ferster witnessed unspeakable horrors in the death camps after being captured by the Nazis aged just 17 Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Chaim Ferster, who inspired thousands after surviving eight concentration camps during the Holocaust, has died aged 94. 
Only in later life was Mr Ferster able to speak of the unspeakable horrors he witnessed in the death camps after being captured by the Nazis in Poland aged just 17. 
He endured the most brutal of existences as he fought for survival in camps including Auschwitz. 
Eventually liberated by the Americans, he and his sister, Manya, came to England in 1946, starting a new life in Cheetham Hill . 
It was not until his late 70s that he was finally able to share his experiences of living in the camps. 
Since then he has dedicated himself to educating others about the Holocaust and the atrocities committed by the Nazis. Chaim Ferster sharing his story with students at Cheadle Hulme School's Sixth Form College (Photo: UGC) 
The father-of-three died on Monday night after suffering a bout of pneumonia and sepsis. 
Family member Hannah Salomon said Mr Ferster was extraordinary. 
“He was a powerful, determined, indefatigable man,” she said. 
“He was committed to making sure the world didn’t ever forget what happened. 
“He was stubborn, defiant and determined to spread the word and was utterly committed despite how painful it was to recount the memories. He didn’t speak about his memories until he had reached quite an advanced age, his late 70s, because it was too painful.” 
Along with Mr Ferster’s three sons and 92-year-old sister Manya, Hannah hopes to recognise a lasting tribute to honour his memory. 
She added: “We have files and files of letters from children and adults whose lives he touched. We’re hoping to use those in some way and create a tribute.” 
Hundreds of people are expected to honour the inspiring speaker during his funeral at Agecroft Jewish Cemetery at 3.45pm this afternoon. (TUES) 
It was just last month when the 94-year-old picked up a violin again for the first time since 1939. Read More Death camp survivor's poignant violin tribute on Holocaust Memorial Day 
The accomplished musician had not played for decades as the instrument triggered traumatic memories as he associated not being able to play it with the times he spent in the death camps. 
But he chose Holocaust Memorial Day to play once more to an enraptured audience at Manchester Grammar School . Chaim Ferster with MGS pupils Ruaidhri Power and Jamie Hamburger (Photo: Manchester Grammar School) 
At the time he said: “It is so important for me to speak about the Holocaust because it must not be forgotten. Six million Jews perished and it must never be forgotten.” 
He spoke about the hunger and brutal conditions in eight different Nazi concentration camps including Auschwitz in Poland. 
He also described the emotional re-union with his younger sister after he was liberated by US soldiers. 
Born into an orthodox Jewish family and raised in the Polish town Sosnowiec, he lost many family members during the Holocaust, before emigrating to England. 
He embarked on a successful career in business and lived in Cheetham Hill until his death. 
In 2015, he was awarded a British Empire Medal for services to Holocaust education.
